I’d hate to miss the train
May be an allusion to One After 909, in which the narrator gets on the wrong train

Everybody had a good year
 Everybody let their hair down
This may be a reference to the Summer of Love, where everybody wanted to be a hippie and ‘let their hair down’

This song was written in 1969 when LSD was at the height of its use. Very often when artists write about seeing the sunshine it is a reference to the use of LSD and other psychedelics. This could be Lennon referencing the widespread use of LSD as “everybody” used it in the late 1960’s and thus saw the sunshine.

“The sunshine” probably refers to Orange Sunshine, a popular/famous brand of LSD in California during 1968 and 1969.

Yeah, yeah! I’ve got a feeling, yeah!
 I’ve got a feeling
This section of the song was written by Paul for his soon to be wife Linda, telling her she was the girl he had always been looking for.
John Lennon did have had a hard year, as he divorced his wife Cynthia, was arrested for drug possession, was nearly broke, and had lost a baby with Yoko Ono through miscarriage.
